loans.use: to increase her inventory (door locks, hinges, door-catcher, etc).

loans.name: Jeffrey

texts.en: Jeffrey works as a security guard to make a living. While on vacant time and weekends, he operates a motor transportation business and offers it for rental purposes. With his income, his previous loan was used for maintenance and was successfully repaid. Recently he borrowed a new loan to purchase new tires. He wants to improve the general living situation of his family in the future.

loans.use: to purchase new tires.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more ice for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more rice, oil, candy, biscuits, etc. for her business.

loans.name: Ismatullo

texts.en:
Ismatullo was born in the year 1966. He has been busy with animal husbandry for more than nine years. Little by little, with the passing of time and years, he has perfected his knowledge. Thanks to the good condition of his animals, he has managed to win a large quantity of customers for his business. He sells his animals in the local market and has many customers. Many of his customers are local butchers whom are made glad by his work. 

He is looking for a loan to buy young cattle. In this way, he will be able to offer his customers good animals and continue to make financial progress, providing his household with good earnings. He awaits your support.

loans.use: to buy cattle for increasing his working capital.

loans.name: Miriam Osogo's Group

texts.en:
Miriam lives in a house made of mud walls, dirt floor and iron roof in Bahani village, Vihiga County, Kenya, with her family that includes 2 children. The community of Bahani village collects their drinking water from a protected spring because there is no piped water supply in this part of rural Kenya. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, often making Bahani’s inhabitants sick and unable to work or attend school.

A new chlorine dispenser program offers a solution to the burden of sickness caused by drinking unsafe water. The dispenser is installed at the local water source where users turn a valve to add chlorine to their jerricans and then collect water as usual. The chlorine disinfects the water and provides residual protection from re-contamination. In Bahani village, 40 households will benefit from having access to safe water through the dispenser. Miriam has volunteered to be the dispenser promoter and will be responsible for refilling the dispenser with chlorine and encouraging the whole community to treat their water in order to keep themselves and their families safe and healthy. There is another volunteer promoter named Robai from the surrounding community who is part of this group loan.

Bahani village needs a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers in the area. Miriam believes that chlorine dispenser use will save them from water-borne diseases. Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce world carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and to make sure that Miriam’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To reduce the burden of water-borne diseases by providing access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Lilian Ombaso's Group

texts.en:
In Vitembe village, Vihiga County, Kenya, Lilian has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program. Lilian is friendly, reliable and a well-liked member of the community with 5 children. Lilian lives with her family in a house made of concrete walls, concrete floor and iron roof.

Vitembe village does not have a piped water supply so the community collects their water from a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water at the point of collection to make it safe to drink. Lilian’s family and 74 other households using the local water sources need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Lilian has volunteered to be the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill the dispenser with chlorine when the tank runs low. Lilian volunteered to be the promoter because she wants to help her community prevent water-borne diseases. Lilian believes that through chlorine dispenser adoption, her community will keep water-borne diseases at bay. There are four other volunteer promoters from the surrounding communities who are part of this group loan: Anjelyne, Jeridah, Linet and Flora.

Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce world carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and to make sure that Lilian’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To install and maintain chlorine dispensers to provide access to safe drinking water for the community

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more used clothing for resale.

loans.name: Avetik

texts.en:
Avetik is 36 years old and lives in Dilijan city. His family consists of his wife and his two school-aged children. For many years until now, Avetik has worked as a distributor of a great variety of construction materials. He works simultaneously with several construction materials shops, which give big orders to Avetik. He must manage to arrange his work in a way so that all the orders must be fulfilled by the end of each day. So, being the only bread winner in his family, Avetik works very hard and with a great sense of responsibility.

Avetik says that with the coming of the warm spring season, it is high time for many people and for companies as well to start or continue different repair and constructional works left incomplete. He needs a loan in order to buy a lot of construction materials, which will help him to manage all his orders on time.

loans.use: to buy a lot of construction materials, which will help him to manage all his orders on time.

loans.name: Rasoa Ajema's Group

texts.en:
Rasoa lives in a house made of mud walls, dirt floor and grass roof in Lianaginga village in Vihiga County, Kenya, with her family that includes 8 children. The community of Lianaginga village collects their drinking water from a protected spring because there is no piped water supply in this part of rural Kenya. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases often making Lianaginga’s inhabitants sick and unable to work or attend school.

A new chlorine dispenser program offers a solution to the burden of sickness caused by drinking unsafe water. The dispenser is installed at the local water source where users turn a valve to add chlorine to their jerricans and then collect water as usual. The chlorine disinfects the water and provides residual protection from re-contamination. In Lianaginga village, 40 households will benefit from having access to safe water through the dispenser. Rasoa has volunteered to be the dispenser promoter and will be responsible for refilling the dispenser with chlorine and encouraging the whole community to treat their water in order to keep themselves and their families safe and healthy. There are four other volunteer promoters from the surrounding communities who are part of this group loan: Esther, Jerida, Benson and Gilbert.

 Lianaginga village needs a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers in the area. Rasoa believes that chlorine dispenser saves lives. Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce world carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and to make sure that Rasoa’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To install and maintain chlorine dispensers to provide access to safe drinking water for the community

loans.name: Mary Ahinga's Group

texts.en:
Mary is 46 years old, has 8 children and lives in Mukuyu village in Vihiga County, Kenya. Mukuyu village does not have a piped water supply so the community collects their water from a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases meaning that Mary and her family may fall sick at any time and become unable to work or attend school.

Mary works as a shop-keeper but has also volunteered her time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables her community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Mary and other promoters in her community, including Margaret, Benson, Mary and Mercelina, need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Mary will encourage the community to treat their water using the dispenser and will also be responsible for refilling the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Mary wants to be the promoter because she believes she can be good at initiating community behaviour change. Mary believes that through regular chlorine dispenser use, her community will avoid water-borne diseases.

Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce world carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and to make sure that Mary’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To ensure that the community has access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Esther Oketch's Group

texts.en:
In Kidumbula village, Vihiga County, Kenya, Esther has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program. Esther is friendly, hardworking, reliable, trustworthy and a well-known member of the community with 3 children. Esther lives with her family in a house made of mud walls, dirt floor and iron roof.

Kidumbula village does not have a piped water supply so the community collects their water from an unprotected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Esther’s family and 60 other households using the local water sources need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Esther has volunteered to be the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill the dispenser with chlorine when the tank runs low. Esther volunteered to be the promoter because she is willing to serve the community. Ether believes that the dispenser will help her community prevent water-borne diseases. There are four other volunteer promoters from the surrounding communities who are part of this group loan: Rosemary, Jane, Naomi and Jackson.

Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce world carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and to make sure that Esther’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To support an innovative water treatment technology - chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Sarah Ombima's Group

texts.en:
Sarah is 39 years old, has 3 children and lives in Kerongo village in Vihiga County, Kenya. Kerongo village does not have a piped water supply so the community collects their water from a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases meaning that Sarah and her family may fall sick at any time and become unable to work or attend school.

Sarah works as a subsistence farmer but has also volunteered her time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables her community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Sarah and other promoters in her community, including Rose, Lydia, Hellen and Judith, need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Sarah will encourage the community to treat their water using the dispenser and will also be responsible for refilling the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Sarah wants to be the promoter because she lives close to the water-point and will always be available when needed. Sarah believes that regular chlorine dispenser use will result in good communal health.

Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce world carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and to make sure that Sarah’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To improve health and productivity by increasing access to safe drinking water through chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Jane Muhonja's Group

texts.en:
Jane is 35 years old, has 2 children and lives in Idumbu village, Vihiga County, Kenya. Idumbu village does not have a piped water supply so the community collects their water from a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Jane and her family may fall sick at any time and become unable to work or attend school.

Jane works as a taxi operator but has also volunteered her time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables her community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Jane and other promoters in her community, including Janet, Dorcillah, Mutinda and Wyclief, need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Jane will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser and will also be responsible for refilling the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Jane wants to be the promoter because her community trusts her and she believes that the chlorine dispenser will kill germs and make their water safe, hence preventing water-borne diseases.

Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce world carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and to make sure that Jane’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To reduce the burden of water-borne diseases by providing access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Mable's Group

texts.en:
Mable lives in a house made of mud walls, dirt floor and iron roof in Chambali village in Vihiga County, Kenya, with her family that includes 5 children. The community of Chambali village collects their drinking water from a protected spring because there is no piped water supply in this part of rural Kenya. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases often making Chambali’s inhabitants sick and unable to work or attend school.

A new chlorine dispenser program offers a solution to the burden of sickness caused by drinking unsafe water. The dispenser is installed at the local water source where users turn a valve to add chlorine to their jerricans and then collect water as usual. The chlorine disinfects the water and provides residual protection from re-contamination. In Chambali village, 34 households will benefit from having access to safe water through the dispenser. Mable has volunteered to be the dispenser promoter and will be responsible for refilling the dispenser with chlorine and encouraging the whole community to treat their water in order to keep themselves and their families safe and healthy. There are four other volunteer promoters from the surrounding communities who are part of this group loan: Tebra, Everlyn, Anne and Josphine.

Chambali village needs a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers in the area. Mable believes that chlorine dispenser adoption will prevent water-borne diseases. Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce world carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and to make sure that Mable’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To provide communities with free access to chlorine dispensers to treat their drinking water

loans.name: Zedekiah Keya's Group

texts.en:
Zedekiah is 65 years old, has 9 children and lives in Gilwatzi village in Vihiga County, Kenya.  Gilwatzi village does not have a piped water supply so the community collects their water from a river. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Zedekiah and his family may fall sick at any time and become unable to work or attend school.

Zedekiah works as a shop-keeper but has also volunteered his time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables his community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Zedekiah and other promoters in his community, including Edith, Noel and Nancy, need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Zedekiah will encourage the community to treat their water using the dispenser and will also be responsible for refilling the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Zedekiah wants to be the promoter because he likes volunteer work and is willing to serve his community. He believes that the chlorine dispenser will greatly contribute to his community’s well-being and prosperity.

Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce world carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and to make sure that Zedekiah’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To allow the community to treat their water to make it safe to drink using chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Dilorom

texts.ru: Ее зовут Дилором. Она из Вахдата. Ей 41 год и она обзаведена семьей. На данный момент Дилором нигде не работает и является безработной. Дилором хочет помочь мужу обеспечить семью и пополняет семейный бюджет. Ранее она занималась животноводством. Для семейных нужд она держала скотин в коровнике. Дилором решила вновь возобновить деятельность животноводства и использовать свои навыки и опыт работы в бизнесе. Она собирается на деньги от кредита купить телят и бычков и после длительного откорма перепродать их с наценкой. На заработанные деньги Дилором надеется улучшить жилищные и жизненные условия. Поддержите Дилорома. Она очень хочет начать бизнес и иметь источник дохода.
texts.en: Her name is Dilorom. She is from Vahdat. She is 41 years old and has a family. Currently, Dilorom doesn't work anywhere and is unemployed. Dilorom wants to help her husband provide for their family and supplement the family's budget. Previously, she practiced animal breeding. To help out the family's needs, she kept cattle in their barn. Dilorom decided to take up the business of livestock breeding again and use her skills and work experience in the business. She is planning to use the money from the loan to buy calves and bull calves to fatten them up for a period of time and then resell them at a markup. With the earned money, Dilorom hopes to improve her home and living conditions. Please support Dilorom. She really wants to start her business and have a source of income.

loans.use: to buy bull calves to raise them and begin her livestock breeding business.

loans.name: Hiyasmin

texts.en: Hiyasmin earns a living from selling snacks in her village. For three years, Hiyasmin has earned well and sustained the business. She had competitors in the village but with her food tasting so well, she never worried for she had her loyal customers who visited her store and made some snacks. To add inventory capital, she borrowed a loan from GDMPC micro credit to purchase raw ingredients for preparing more snacks to sell. She hopes to have more returns in order to generate additional income for the purpose of renovating her house.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients for preparing more snacks to sell.

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella is a 36-year-old woman. She has three children, with ages ranging from two years to nine years. She describes herself as being trustworthy. 

She operates a farm where she grows cabbages, spinach, and other vegetables to sell. Her business is located in an area with high productivity and it is business-friendly. Her primary customers are of all types. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate finances to boost business. 

Stella will use the KES 50,000 loan to buy vegetable seeds for planting. Her business goal is to have a business that yields high returns within five years. 

Stella hopes that, in the future, the business will enable her family to buy land and build a house. This is her second loan with SMEP Deposit Taking Microfinance Limited (SMEP DTM). Her previous loan of KES 20,000 was successfully repaid.

loans.use: to buy vegetable seeds for planting.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase variety of plastic slippers for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more stationery to expand his business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more slippers for her business

loans.name: Pedro Alexander

texts.es: Pedro de 49 años de edad vive en casa propia con su familia, desde hace varios años se dedica a la compra y venta de hierro, aluminio, plástico, etc. posee clientela establecida que lo buscan por los buenos precios, con lo que obtiene de sus ganancias logra solventar algunos gastos de su hogar, Pedro esta solicitando un crédito para poder comprar mas productos reciclables y asi darle a su familia una mejor estabilidad económica.
texts.en: Pedro is 49 years old. He has lived in his own home with his family for several years. His business is the purchase and sale of iron, aluminum, plastics, etc. He has an established clientele who seek him out for his good prices, from which he obtains enough earnings to settle some household expenses. Pedro is requesting a loan to buy more recycled products so he can give his family better economic stability.

loans.use: to buy recycled products such as iron, aluminum, plastics, etc.

loans.name: Ruby

texts.en:
Ruby grows and sells pigs in town, work that she has done for a year. Her husband works for a private company as a laborer since it was the only way they had to move the family forward. She gets up early and has to oversee her pigs.

Ruby is requesting this loan to buy feed since she needs it to boost her pigs.  In the future, she wants to have a better house than she has now and she wants to be able to give her children the education she did not have.

loans.use: to buy feed for her pigs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more used clothes for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy used socks to expand her business

loans.name: Kenjebubu

texts.ru: Кенжебубу 48 лет, замужем, воспитывает 1 сына. У Кенжебубу - среднее образование, имеет очень хорошие отзывы от своих соседей. Они отзываются о ней как о доброй и трудолюбивой женщине. Кенжебубу в качестве основного дохода для своей семьи, с 1996 года занимается торговлей продовольственных товаров и продуктов питания, начала этот бизнес с 9,500 сом KGS. Благодаря упорному труду Кенжебубу, она смогла развить и расширить свой товар, ее деятельность приносит около 10,000 сом KGS в месяц, что служит основой для покрытия расходов на питание и бытовые нужды семьи. Доходы от бизнеса и животноводства позволили Кенжебубу расширить свой товарооборот. В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Кенжебубу обратилась в Банк "Бай-Тушум" за кредитом - на покупку оптовых товаров продуктов питания для дальнейшей перепродажи. Доходы от кредита Кенжебубу планирует вложить в дальнейшее увеличение своего бизнеса, а также в будущем намерена заняться реконструкцией дома.
texts.en: Kenjebubu is 48 years old, married, and raising one son. Kenjebubu has a secondary education. Her neighbors have good things to say about her. They describe her as a kind and hardworking woman. As the main source of income for her family, Kenjebubu has sold groceries and food products since 1996. She started this business with 9,500 som (KGS). Thanks to Kenjebubu's hard work, she has been able to develop and expand her merchandise. This business brings in around 10,000 som (KGS) per month, which serves as the basis for covering her family's food and daily living expenses. The profits from this business and from livestock breeding have allowed Kenjebubu to expand her sales volume. For the purpose of further developing her business, Kenjebubu turned to Microfinance Bank "Bai Tushum." She is requesting a loan to buy wholesale food items for future retail sale. Kenjebubu plans to invest the earnings from the loan to further increase her business. She also intends to save money to perform a reconstruction of her house in the future.

loans.use: to buy wholesale food items for future retail sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more stocks of bananas.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more used clothes for her business.

loans.name: Sony Group

texts.en:
Saada, who is in her early 40s, is married with three daughters, one of whom goes to school. The other two are grown-ups.  She has been running two projects, having a poultry business and a tailoring business.  She has been in her businesses for two years now. She works from 4 am to 8 pm daily and is able to make a very good monthly profit.

This will be Saada's first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She wants to use this loan to buy chicks, chicken feed and materials for the tailoring business.  She dreams of becoming an international businesswoman. 

Saada will share this loan with her loan group "Sony" which has three members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to  buy chicks, chicken feed and materials for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Omran

texts.en:
Omran is a 19-year-old single man who started in January 2013 his own car tire repair and sales business to improve his standard of living and plan his own career path.
Omran started this kind of business seven years ago, when he had to quit his elementary studies to support his family.
Today, Omran is acquiring a YOUTH loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua to increase his tire capital with newly released items that are heavy duty and affordable to his customers.
He hopes that in the future he can develop his business, through buying his own work place instead of renting from others.

loans.use: To increase his tire capital with newly released items that are heavy duty and affordable to his customers

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is asking for a loan because she believes that through it, she will improve her business .

The previous loan has enabled her to save money from her food stall business. She is requesting a loan of Ksh.25,000 to purchase maize flour, wheat flour, and rice for her business.

She feels that she was able to make a good investment with her previous loan, which to date has allowed her to maintain her level of profits to help her family cover their personal expenses.

loans.use: to purchase maize flour, wheat flour, and rice for her business.

loans.name: Solphiline

texts.en: Solphiline is a 26 year old married woman. She has 2 children. She describes herself to be ambitious. She operates a retail business where she sells washing soap, sugar, maize flour and other items. She has been involved in this business for 2 years. Her business is located in a good place and her primary customers are of all types. She describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of enough stock to sell. She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy more stock of soap, sugar, bread and other items for resale. Her business goal is to be a wholesaler within 5 years. She will use the anticipated profits to expand her business further.

loans.use: buy more stock of soap, sugar, bread and other items for resale

loans.name: Truphena

texts.en:
Meet Truphena: a farmer living in the Eldoret area of North Rift, Kenya. She is married and has 5 children, all of school-going age.  She has been farming for six years, with her income coming from the sale of milk and crops. She loves feeding and taking care of her livestock, but her biggest challenge is acquiring feed during the dry season.

Truphena chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan because they offer small-scale dairy financing. During her training, she learnt how to develop a saving culture. The income from this loan will improve Truphena's cash flow. This will help her to better educate her children and also improve her family's living standards.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more food ingredients for her cook shop (restaurant)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase medical drugs to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more rice, peppers, fish, oil, meat, etc,. for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchasing more cooking oil, rice and cooking seasonings to expand her business.

loans.name: Tahira

texts.en:
Tahira is a 55-year-old refugee. She is a widow and lives with a daughter and a son in an IDP settlement. She is a farmer and raises seasonal vegetables such as cucumbers, potatoes, tomatoes and greens. Her monthly income is 120 AZN. 

Tahira has worked in this field for 34 years and she knows everything of farming. She also knows that seasonal vegetables aren't as profitable as she wants. But unfortunately she cannot raise other kinds of vegetables because of the cold climate in her region. People have high demands for fresh vegetables, especially greens because they are very good for health. People also use greens to prepare such national dishes as green qutab, dovgha, doghramaj, etc.

Tahira’s income is not enough for her to cover her family’s demands. She decided to build a greenhouse for her vegetables and buy additional vegetable seeds. That is why she applied for 1500 AZN loan from the credit union. She believes that this will help her to increase her income and be able to escape  debts in future.

loans.use: to build a greenhouse for her garden

loans.name: Mt Magoroto Group

texts.en:
AMOSI, who is in his late 30s is single.  He has been running a telephone accessories business for three years now.  He works from 08 am to 08 pm daily and is able to make a very good monthly profit. 

This will be AMOSI's 3rd loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  He used the previous loans to buy different types of accessories and has repaid all his loans successfully.  He uses the profit to cover household expenses. He will use this loan buy new telephone accessories. He dreams of improving his shop to international standards.

Amosi will share this loan with his loan group "MT MAGOROTO" which has six members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy new telephone accessories.

loans.name: Mary Flor

texts.en: Mary Flor is 47 years old, married and has two children. She owns and manages a small variety store within her community while her husband works as a government employee. She aims to improve her business in order to help her husband in financing the education of their children. Due to insufficient capital, she decided to seek a loan of PHP 28,000 to buy additional stocks of grocery items such as canned goods,biscuits,junk foods and detergent soap to sell.Through this loan, she believes that she will further improve the business and make it more profitable in the future.

loans.use: to buy more grocery items such as canned goods,biscuits,junk foods and detergent soap to sell

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida is thankful for the financial assistance extended to her. She was able to buy more products for her variety store. Her loan helped not just in her business but also in the education of her children. Her income from business is assisting with their everyday household expenditures. She and her husband are working hard to provide for their everyday household expenditures. She also has a food stall for additional income.

She would like to apply for another 50,000 PHP loan for her to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and children’s education expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Aida dreams that her store will grow bigger as well as hopes to give her children a good life and education. Every week, she meets with her co-fellowship members* to share stories of her life and business as well as to draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and from her studies of the Word of God.

*All Center for Community Transformation (CCT) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is a 38-year-old married woman. She has five children with ages ranging from 8 to 18 years. She describes herself to be trustworthy. She operates a retail business where she sells charcoal. She has been involved in this business for four years. Her business is located in a convenient and accessible place and her primary customers are regular customers. 

Rehema describes her biggest business challenge to be high transport costs. She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy more stock of charcoal. Her business goal is to be a wholesaler within five years. This is her second loan with SMEP DTM. Her previous loan of Kes 20,000 was repaid successfully. She will use the anticipated profits to open other branches.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal to stock for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more ingredients for preparing the food she sells

loans.name: Ma. Morina

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Ma. Morina works hard to support her family.

She has a fishing business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from pig fattening. Ma. Morina is borrowing 16,000 PHP through NWTF to buy fishing materials for her fishing business.

Ma. Morina has been sustaining her business activities through her past seven loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so that she can buy land.

loans.use: to buy fishing materials for her business

loans.name: Zaripa

texts.ru: Зарипе 47 лет, замужем, вместе с супругом воспитывают 3 детей. У Зарипы - среднее образование, в качестве основного дохода для своей семьи Зарипа занимается полеводством и животноводством, стартовав 25 лета назад, с 1,000 сом KGS. Благодаря упорному труду Зарипы, на сегодняшний день имеется: 1 дойная корова, также имеется 1,30 ГА земельной доли, на которой ежегодно выращивает перец, помидоры, арбузы, хлопок для внутрихозяйственного потребления и реализации. Ежемесячный доход составляет 10,000 сом (KGS). В целях дальнейшего развития своего хозяйства, Зарипа обратилась в Банк "Бай-Тушум" за кредитом для закупа высококачественных семян перца, помидоров, арбузов, хлопка для посевных работ и удобрений для обработки земли. Зарипа намерена получить хороший урожай, что непременно приведет к увеличению капитала семьи. Доходы от кредита Зарипа планирует вложить в приумножение количества домашней скотины, и планирует накопить средства на покупку бытовой техники.
texts.en: Zaripa is 47 years old, married, and together with her husband, is raising three children. Zaripa has a secondary education. As the main source of income for her family, Zaripa practices livestock breeding and crop farming. She started this business 25 years ago with 1,000 som (KGS). Thanks to Zaripa's hard work, she currently has 1 milk cow on her farm, as well as a 1.30 hectare plot of land on which she annually grows peppers, tomatoes, watermelons and cotton for personal consumption and sale. Her monthly income is 10,000 som (KGS). For the purpose of further developing her business, Zaripa turned to Microfinance Bank "Bai Tushum." She is requesting a loan to buy high quality pepper, tomato, watermelon and cotton seeds for sowing as well as fertilizers for cultivating the land. Zaripa is determined to receive a good harvest which will fundamentally increase her family's capital. Zaripa plans to invest the earnings from the loan in the further acquisition of livestock. She also intends to save money to buy household appliances.

loans.use: to buy tomato, pepper, watermelon and cotton seeds as well as fertilizers.

loans.name: Hat

texts.en:
Originally from Koh Sotin district of Kampong Cham Province, Hat is a thirty-two-year-old married father with one child. To better feed his family, Hat works as a carpenter while his wife sells grocery items. From current businesses, he and his wife are able to earn about US$17 per day. 

Hat has just joined Vision Fund and is applying for a loan to buy a decent motorbike for his family to commute. He hopes this loan will enable him to have a proper motorbike to use in his family.

loans.use: to buy a decent motorbike for his family to commute

location.town: Kampong Cham Province, Koh Sotin District

loans.name: Criselda

texts.en:
Criselda is a 45-year-old woman from the community of Garcia-Hernandez, Bohol. She is married, and her husband works as a construction worker. They have three children; her eldest is 27, and her youngest is 10. 

Criselda has been selling silver and fancy jewelries for 15 years now. She is asking for a loan to buy more stock of the silver and Swarovski type. She hopes that with the additional capital she can expand her business and eventually increase profitability to support her family.

loans.use: to buy silver and Swarovski

loans.name: Jacklyn

texts.en:
Jacklyn works hard to support her family. She is married and has a fishing business in the Philippines.

She requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional fishing net for her fishing business.

Jacklyn has been in this business for two years now. She would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional fishing net for her fishing business

loans.name: Ken

texts.en:
Ken is 45 years old and a resident of Kampong Cham province. She is a local farmer who grows rice and cassava as her main source of income. She has been involved in her current business for several years.  This is not the first loan for Ken with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). With the successful repayment of her past loan, she was able to improve her lifestyle and make it better than before. 

For this cycle, Ken is seeking 4,000,000 KHR in order to pay for cassava farmland leasing fee. She hopes that she can earn a better income than before.

loans.use: To pay for cassava farmland leasing fee.

loans.name: Saida

texts.en:
Saida is 30 years old and has three children, one of whom is in school.

She earns a living by fattening pigs in the Philippines. Saida is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Saida has been fattening pigs for 3 years and also earns additional income from her general store.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: George

texts.en: George is single and provides transportation services in his village. He plans to improve his parent's farm from out of his earnings. He took out a loan from Gata Daku Multi-purpose Cooperative (GDMPC) to cover maintenance costs for his motorcycle. George wants to improve the general living situation of his family and dreams of having a farm of his own in the future.

loans.use: to pay for motor maintenance costs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy cattle.

loans.name: Aigul

texts.ru: Айгул 27 лет, замужем, вместе с супругом воспитывают 3 детей. У Айгул - среднее образование. Вместе с мужем Айгул занимается животноводством и полеводством, стартовав 8 лет назад, с покупки скота на 30,000 сом KGS. Благодаря упорному труду Айгул, в ее хозяйстве на сегодняшний день имеется: 4 дойные коровы, 12 овец. Ежемесячный доход составляет 15,000 сом (KGS) от реализации молока, также обрабатывает 2,34 ГА земли, где в основном выращивает -арбузы, помидоры, перец и хлопок. Полученный урожай реализуют оптовым поставщикам. В целях дальнейшего развития своего хозяйства, Айгул обратилась в Банк "Бай-Тушум"  за кредитом - на покупку коров для увеличения поголовья скота. После закупки коров, они будут находиться в собственном хозяйстве. Летом скот будет под присмотром пастуха. Доходы от кредита Айгул планирует вложить в дальнейшее приумножение количества домашней скотины, и планирует накопить средства на покупку семейной автомашины.
texts.en: Aigul is 27 years old, married, and together with her husband, is raising three children. Aigul has a secondary education. Aigul and her husband practice livestock breeding and crop farming. She started this business 8 years ago, with an initial purchase of cattle in the amount of 30,000 som (KGS). Thanks to Aigul's hard work, she currently has 4 milk cows and 12 sheep on her farm. Her monthly income is 15,000 som (KGS) from the sale of milk as well as from cultivating a 2.34 hectare plot of land on which she mainly grows watermelons, tomatoes, peppers and cotton. The received harvest is sold to wholesale distributors. For the purpose of further developing her business, Aigul turned to Microfinance Bank "Bai Tushum." She is requesting a loan to buy cows to increase the size of her herd. After purchasing the cattle, they will be located on her farm. In the summer, they will be under the care of a shepherd. Aigul plans to invest the earnings from the loan in the further acquisition of livestock. She also intends to save money to buy a family car.

loans.use: to buy cows.

loans.name: Vaise

texts.en: Vaise is a 47-year-old married woman with eight children. She runs a small business selling coconut buns in her community and has been doing this for six years. Vaise has requested a loan to buy bags of sugar, flour, coconut, etc. She joined SPBD in 2011 to gain access to capital. With her earnings, Vaise plans to earn a good living in order to develop her family's standard of living.

loans.use: to buy bags of sugar, flour, coconut, etc.

loans.name: Mushviga

texts.en:
Mushviga is 48 years old and married with a daughter and a son. The family is IDP and has lived in an IDP settlement for a long time. Her husband is a driver. Mushviga has been earning money from farming for 20 years and has gained good skills. She raises crops and seasonal fruit trees (quince, persimmon, etc.). Her monthly income is 200 AZN. She gets additional income by raising hens and cocks. 

Quince and persimmon are very delicious and useful fruits, especially when fresh. People like these fruits because of their taste and use them for preparing jams and juice. 

Mishviga needs money to repair her house. She applied for 1500 AZN loan in order to buy new fertilizers and garden tools. She plans to increase her income and be able to repair her house in the future and make it better. This is her second loan and she has a positive client history.

loans.use: to buy new fertilizers and garden tools

loans.name: Adelina

texts.en: Adelina, a mother of four, has managed a general store for more than ten years and she earns well to support her husband’s income. She has sustained it with the support of the entire family. The couple wants to provide a better education to their children. She has successfully repaid her previous loan, which was used for buying stocks of groceries. Recently, she took a new loan from GDMPC micro credit to buy additional grocery goods to sell. In the future, she wants to improve the business as well as the general condition of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional grocery goods to sell.

loans.name: Sri

texts.en:
Sri lives in West Bandung, about three hours from Jakarta. Sri manages a small shop selling household appliances and mobile phone airtime credit.  Sri is married and lives with four people in the family home.

Sri joined Ruma one month ago because she found it interesting to sell mobile phone airtime credits.  With assistance and support from Ruma’s staff, Sri sees improvements in her shop.  For the last month, she earns an average of $28 - 29 per day in mobile phone airtime credit sales.  She hopes to get a Kiva loan as working capital to process more transactions.  Her goal for her business is to expand and have more new business in the future

loans.use: to process more mobile phone airtime credit transactions on weekends

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is a 37-year-old woman. She describes herself to be honest. She operates a retail shop where she sells bread, flour, sugar and other items. She has been involved in this business for three years. Her business is located in an area with lots of customers and her primary customers are loyal. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate funds. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy more stock of wheat flour, sugar and other items for resale. Her business goal is to expand within five years. She hopes that in the future, the business will enable her to acquire wealth to invest in other ventures. This is her first loan with SMEP-DTM.

loans.use: to buy more stock of wheat flour, sugar and other items for resale

loans.name: Kunduzkhan

texts.ru: Кундузхан 57 лет, замужем, вместе с супругом воспитывают 4 детей. У Кундузхан - высшее образование, работала бухгалтером в местной школе, на данный момент на пенсии. В качестве основного дохода для своей семьи Кундузхан занимается животноводством, стартовав 21 год назад, с покупки скота на 3,500 сом KGS. Благодаря упорному труду Кундузхан, в ее хозяйстве на сегодняшний день имеется: 5 дойных коров, 15 овец. Ежемесячный доход составляет 10,000 сом (KGS). В целях дальнейшего развития своего хозяйства, Кундузхан обратилась в Банк «Бай –Тушум» за кредитом - на покупку коров для увеличения поголовья скота. Доходы от кредита Кундузхан планирует вложить в дальнейшее приумножение количества домашней скотины, и планирует накопить средства на покупку нового холодильника.
texts.en: Kunduzkhan is 57 years old, married, and together with her husband, is raising four children. Kunduzkhan has a higher education. She worked as an accountant at a local school, but she is currently retired. As the main source of income for her family, Kunduzkhan practices livestock breeding. She started this business 21 years ago, with an initial purchase of cattle in the amount of 3,500 som (KGS). Thanks to Kunduzkhan's hard work, she currently has 5 milk cows and 15 sheep on her farm. Her monthly income is 10,000 som (KGS). For the purpose of further developing her business, Kunduzkhan turned to Microfinance Bank "Bai Tushum." She is requesting a loan to buy cows to increase the size of her herd. Kunduzkhan plans to invest the earnings from the loan in the further acquisition of livestock. She also intends to save money to buy a new refrigerator.

loans.use: to buy cows.

loans.name: Minura

texts.en:
Minura is 24 years old, single and lives with parents. The members of her family are refugees and live in an IDP settlement. The only source of income for the family is farming. Minura raises fruits and vegetables and then sells them at a local bazaar. She has been working in this area for three years and her monthly income is 120 AZN. 

Azerbaijan people like eating fresh vegetables because it’s useful for their health. In addition, vegetables are used in preparing different national dishes, such as badimjhan dolmasi, kelem dolmasi, dovgha, etc. People use fruits to cook fruitcakes or jams for dessert.

Minura’s parents are old and ill. So, Minura needs to increase her income in order to be able to take care of her parents and pay for their medicines. She applied for 1,500 AZN to buy new sorts of fruit trees and expand her small business. She is a very hardworking and responsible person and does everything in order to help her parents.

loans.use: to buy new varieties of fruit trees

loans.name: Hector

texts.es:
Hector vive en casa de sus padres en la ciudad de La Paz, trabaja en la Alcaldia. Tambien se dedica a la venta de productos para la salud. Debido a una estafa perdio este negocio y entro en quiebra.

El credito que solicita es para reinvertir en productos de salud para adelgazar, pero siendo independiente en esta ocasión, así podra mejorar sus ingresos, ya que su sueldo es bajo y no le alcanza para cubrir los gastos de su familia.
 
El sueño de Hector  es poder tener su propia tienda.
texts.en:
Hector lives in his parents’ house in the city of La Paz.  He works for the local government.  He also sells health products.  Due to a scam, he lost this business and entered into bankruptcy.

The loan he is requesting is to reinvest in health products for losing weight.  However, he is now working independently.  This way he will be able to improve his income.  His salary is low, and it does not cover his family’s expenses.

Hector’s dream is to be able to have his own store.

loans.use: to buy health products for his independent business.

loans.name: Seyran

texts.en:
Seyran is 45 years old and he lives in Ijevan city in Tavus region. He is married and he has a school-aged son and a daughter. His wife is a nurse and she works at a hospital. 

Seyran used to work as a hoist man at the railway station, and then for several years he had a vegetable trading business at the Ijevan wholesale market, but having little income and working in a falling economy made Seyarn go to the Russian Federation. For 14 years he lived and worked there, doing very different work, which brought in some money for living. 

Two years ago he decided to return to his hometown Ijevan. Here he bought a truck and being skilled in the trading business he again started vegetable and fruit selling, but this time he did it on a wholesale basis. On his truck he brings products from Yerevan and sells them to his already loyal customers at the wholesale market of the city.

loans.use: to repay the money he borrowed from his friends as a debt to buy a truck

loans.name: Ainura

texts.ru: Айнуре 26 лет, замужем, вместе с супругом воспитывают 2 детей. У Айнуры - высшее образование, работает бухгалтером в сельской управе. В качестве дополнительного дохода для своей семьи Айнура занимается полеводством и животноводством, стартовав 8 лет назад, с 5,000 сом KGS. Благодаря упорному труду Айнуры, на сегодняшний день имеется: 1 дойная корова, 2 теленка, также имеется 6,20 ГА земельной доли, на которой ежегодно выращивает фасоль для внутрихозяйственного потребления и реализации. Ежемесячный совокупныЙ доход составляет 16,000 сом (KGS). В целях дальнейшего развития своего хозяйства, Айнура обратилась в Банк "Бай-Тушум" за кредитом для закупа высококачественных семян фасоли посевных работ. Айнура намерена получить хороший урожай, что непременно приведет к увеличению капитала семьи. Доходы от кредита Айнура планирует вложить в приумножение количества домашней скотины, и планирует накопить средства на дальнейшее образование детей.
texts.en: Ainura is 26 years old and married; she and her husband are raising two children. Ainura has received a college  degree. She works as an accountant for the village administration. As an additional source of income for her family, Ainura grows produce and raises livestock, having launched this eight years ago with a starting capital of 5,000 KGS. Thanks to Ainura's hard work, at present she has one dairy cow and two calves. She also has a land plot of 6.2 ha [15.3 acres], where she  annually grows beans for family use as well as for sale. The total income from her farm is 16,000 KGS. In order to develop her farm further, Ainura has applied to the Bai Tushum & Partners microfinance institution for a loan to buy high-quality bean seeds before the planting season. Ainura plans to have a large harvest, which will no doubt increase her family's working capital. Ainura plans to use the revenues for her loan to increase her livestock. She also plans to save up to pay for future education of her children.

loans.use: to buy bean seeds.

loans.name: Zafarjon

texts.en: Zafarjon was born in 1988. He is a young and hardworking man. Zafarjon is married and has two children. He has his own business growing potatoes and carrots. He has his own land and works there with pleasure. He began his business six years ago. He always wanted to get a higher degree but he did not have that opportunity. He works hard but still has poor living conditions. He lives with his wife, children and parents in a house, which is in bad condition. He is going to repair his house and that’s why he is asking for a loan of 2,000 Somoni to buy building materials as cement, wood, paints, etc. He awaits your support.

loans.use: To buy building materials such as cement, wood, and paints to repair his house

loans.name: Andriyana

texts.en:
Andriyana lives in West Bandung, about three hours from Jakarta. Andriyana manages a small shop selling mobile accessories and mobile phone airtime credit.  Andriyana is married and lives with five persons in the family house.

Andriyana joined Ruma one month ago because he found it interesting to sell mobile phone airtime credits. With assistance and support from Ruma’s staff, Andriyana sees improvements in his shop.  For the last month, he earned an average of $19 -20 per day in mobile phone airtime credit sales.  He hopes to get a Kiva loan as working capital to process more transactions.  His goal for his business is to expand and have more new business in the future

loans.use: to process more mobile phone airtime credit transactions on weekends

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn is a married woman from Bohol, Philippines and a mother of two children who are eight and six years old. She has earned a living through vegetable farming with her husband for more than eight years now. They grow several kinds of vegetables on their farm. This is the source of their income.

Marilyn is asking for a loan to buy vegetable seeds and fertilizer. With this, she will be able to grow healthy vegetables, thus improving the harvest that she can sell to the market. Marilyn hopes to make their vegetable farming a success. She also wants to continue to support her children's education.

loans.use: to buy vegetable seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Marcos

texts.es:
Marcos vive en  casa de los suegros en la ciudad de La Paz, en compañia de su esposa e hijo, de profesion ingeniero en sistemas, trabaja en una institucion donde percibe un sueldo minimo, la esposa tambien trabaja y aporta en la familia.

El credito que solicita es para concluir la construccion de su departamento, que fue heredado por su suegra.

El sueño de Marco  es poder tener su propia oficina y ya no depender de un jefe.
texts.en:
Marcos lives with his wife and son in his parents-in-law’s house in the city of La Paz. He is a systems engineer and he works in an institution where he receives a minimum wage. His wife also works and contributes financially to the family.

The loan he is requesting is for finishing the construction of his apartment, which his mother-in-law inherited.

Marcos' dream is to be able to have his own office and not be accountable to a boss.

loans.use: to finish building his apartment

loans.name: Vera

texts.en:
Vera, whose name in Albanian means summer, is a 43-year-old married mother of three.
 
Vera practices livestock; she’s got a few cows and goats, with the latest being her preferred ones. 

"It is very easy to look after goats versus other animals because: a) we don’t have to buy that much fodder for them, since they graze in the mountains around, b) most of the times, they need no one to go with them, since the whole flock goes and comes back together from grazing, and c) they don’t occupy too much space in the stable and they keep the space cleaner that cows, and lastly, the goat cheese is more pricey that the cow cheese” said Vera during her interview.

Considering all of the above, Vera wants to add 12 more goats to the existing herd.

loans.use: to add 12 more goats to the existing herd.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married woman with three children, two of whom attend school and one is underage. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For over five years, she has operated a fruits and vegetable stall business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. She dreams of establishing a grocery store in the future.

With the KES 50,000, she wants to purchase green vegetables, fruits, tomatoes, potatoes and onions for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase green vegetables, fruits, tomatoes, potatoes and onions for resale

loans.name: Philomena

texts.en: Philomena is a 38-year-old married woman. She has two children who are three and seven years old. She describes herself to be goal oriented and trustworthy. She operates a retail business where she sells oranges, bananas and curtains. She has been involved in this business for four years. Her business is located in a business-friendly area. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate finances. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy more stock of oranges, bananas and curtains. Her business goal is to increase operations and open a new branch within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will open a general shop. This is her third loan with SMEP-DTM. Her previous loan of KES 10,000 was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stock of oranges, bananas and curtains

loans.name: Mayrelin Esther

texts.es:
Mayrelin Esther es una joven estudiante de Arquitectura, ella solicita un préstamo para poder cubrir sus gastos educativos, esta es su historia: Mi nombre es Mayrelin Esther, tengo 18 años y vivo en la Romana. Mi padre trabaja en una tienda de repuesto para vehículos y mi madre tiene una pequeña tienda.
Decidí estudiar arquitectura en la Universidad Central del Este (UCE) ya que desde muy pequeña me siento atraída por esta carrera universitaria y más que eso es un sueño que quiero hacer realidad para tener un futuro como una Buena profesional arquitecta. Debido a que mis padres no pueden costear la matrícula de esta carrera estoy pidiendo un préstamo KIVA para costear la matrícula y compra de materiales ya que esta carrera requiere de realizar muchos proyectos y trabajos en grupos. Necesito una ayuda y sin ella no podré estudiar. Mi familia, principalmente mi madre, tiene muchos deseos de que yo termine mis estudios y verme graduada, y yo quisiera cumplirle ese sueño.
Soy una excelente estudiante con un promedio de 92 en el bachillerato, y voy a poner mucha dedicación y empeño en mis estudios para poder graduarme con honores y ayudar a mis padres económicamente, y aportar algo a mi país como una profesional dispuesta a ayudar y a brindar conocimientos.
texts.en:
Mayrelin Esther is a young architecture student. She is requesting a loan so she can cover her educational expenses. This is her story:
 
“My name is Mayrelin Esther. I am 18 years old and I live in La Romana. My father works in a spare parts store and my mother has a small store.

I decided to study architecture at Universidad Central Del Este (UCE) because I have felt attracted to this university degree since I was a little girl and, moreover, it is a dream that I want to make a reality in order to have a future as a good architect. As my parents cannot pay the fees for the degree, I am requesting a Kiva loan in order to pay my fees and purchase materials, since this degree requires me to do lots of projects and group work. I need help and without it I will not be able to study. My family, particularly my mother, really want me to finish my studies and graduate, and I would like to fulfil this dream.

I am an excellent student with an average of 92% at high school, and I am going to put a lot of dedication and effort into my studies in order to graduate with honours, help my parents financially, and contribute something to my country as a professional ready to help and offer knowledge."

loans.use: to pay for her university expenses

loans.name: Roxana Elizabeth

texts.es: Roxana tiene 29 años de edad y habita en casa propia junto a su compañero de vida y su pequeño hijo de tres años de edad. Roxana tiene más de un año de dedicarse a la venta de tortillas las cuales son muy demandadas por sus clientes. Ella desea invertir en la compra de puertas y ventanas para la cocina dado que no cuenta con ellas por lo que solicita este crédito a FUSAI para hacer la inversión y dar mayor seguridad a sus pocas pertenencias. Espera poder contar con este financiamiento dado que no puede hacer la inversión por su cuenta pero si con la capacidad de pago mensual que el crédito implica.
texts.en: Roxana is 29 years old and lives in her own house with her partner and her three-year-old son. Roxana has been selling tortillas, which are in high demand, for more than a year. She wishes to invest in the purchase of doors and windows for the kitchen, since she does not have them at the moment. For this reason, she is requesting a loan from FUSAI in order to make the investment and give greater security to her few belongings. She hopes to be able to receive this financing as she cannot make the investment herself upfront, but she can with the monthly repayments the loan offers.

loans.use: to buy doors and windows for her kitchen

loans.name: Ana Victoria

texts.es: Ana tiene 44 años de edad y habita en casa propia junto a su esposo y su hija. Ana trabaja como empleada en un tienda en la zona urbana de su localidad. Tiene dos años de contar con este empleo y es lo que le permite ajustar junto  a su esposo para cubrir los gastos del hogar. Ana desea terminar de construir su cocina dado que por falta de recursos económicos no ha logrado terminarla. Por lo anterior solicita este crédito a FUSAI para invertir en la compra de puertas, ventanas, cemento y arena para dar mayor seguridad a la vivienda y para mejorar las paredes de la misma.
texts.en: Ana is 44 years old and lives in her own house with her husband and daughter. Ana works as an employee in a store in the urban area of her town. She has had this job for two years and, together with her husband’s work, it is what enables her to cover the household expenses. Ana wishes to finish building her kitchen, since she has not been able to finish it yet due to the lack of funds. For this reason, she is requesting this loan from FUSAI so she can invest in the purchase of doors, windows, cement, and sand to make her home more secure and improve the walls of her house.

loans.use: to buy doors, windows, cement, and sand to make her kitchen more secure and to improve the walls of the kitchen

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys is a 28-year-old single woman. She has one child. She describes herself to be hardworking and self-driven. She operates a retail business where she sells bananas and oranges. She has been involved in this business for three years. 

Her primary customers are both wholesalers and retailers. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy more stocks of bananas and oranges. Her business goal is to expand within five years. She will use the anticipated profits to pay school fees for her child.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of bananas and oranges.

loans.name: Leila

texts.en:
Leila is a divorced woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For over two years, she has been operating a fruits and vegetable stall business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. She dreams of establishing a grocery store in the future.

With the KES 50,000, she wants to purchase a stock of green vegetables, fruits, tomatoes, potatoes, and onions for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase a stock of green vegetables, fruits, tomatoes, potatoes, and onions for resale.

loans.name: Agus

texts.en:
Agus lives in West Bandung, about three hours from Jakarta. Agus manages a small shop selling mobile accesories and mobile phone airtime credit.  Agus is married and lives with five persons in the family house.
	
Agus joined Ruma one month ago because he finds it interesting to sell mobile phone airtime credits. With assistance and support from Ruma’s staff, Agus sees improvements in his`shop. For the last month, he earned an average of $55 -56 per day in mobile phone airtime credit sales.  He hopes to get a Kiva loan as working capital to process more transactions.  His goal for his business is to expand and have more new business in the future

loans.use: to process more mobile phone airtime credit transactions on weekends

loans.name: Flowrence

texts.en:
Flowrence is a single woman. She has one school-going child. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

Flowrence operates a cereal selling business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality.

With the KES 30,000 she wants to purchase sacks of rice for resale. She joined Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of rice for resale.

loans.name: Ruben

texts.es:
Ruben vive junto a sus padres en la ciudad de La Paz, es de profesion abogado, trabaja realizando tramites en la calle por mas de ocho horas, debido a la escasez de trabajo en el area legal.
 
El credito le será útil para comprar una computadora que le servirá para seguir elaborando memoriales. El equipo con el que ha estado trabajando se ha averiado por la lluvia y no tiene arreglo, ademas, se trata de un equipo obsoleto

El sueño de Ruben es poder tener su propia oficina
texts.en:
Ruben lives with his parents in the city of La Paz.  He is a lawyer, and because there is so little work in his field he works in the streets for more than eight hours a day completing legal paperwork. He will use the loan to buy a computer which will be useful in continuing to file the documents. The machine he has been using has been damaged by rain and cannot be repaired. Furthermore, it is obsolete.

Ruben's dream is to have his own office.

loans.use: to buy a computer.

loans.name: Raymundo

texts.en:
Raymundo is a farmer from Bohol, Philippines. He is a married man and has two grown children. Raymundo has been in the vegetable farming business for more than 18 years now. He grows various kinds of vegetables in his farm. 

Raymundo is asking for a loan to buy seeds, fertilizer, and sprayer. With this, he will be able to improve the productivity of his farm, thus augment his harvest and yield. 

In the future, Raymundo hopes to make his farming business a success.

loans.use: to buy seeds,  fertilizer, and sprayer.

loans.name: Saum

texts.en: Saum appreciates her previous Kiva loan, which improved her living standards and enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income. Saum is requesting a loan of KES 50,000 to purchase more sacks of cashew nuts for her business. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase more sacks of cashew nuts for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy bricks, cement, sand, iron, and sand to build a retaining wall

loans.name: Konokouloudjele Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe KONOKOULOUDJELE est composé de femmes mariées elles ont en moyenne 48 ans, et 5 enfants. Elles vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles dans le village de Bouya, commune de Banco, préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région administrative de la République du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce de couscous séché, de noix de néré, de cola, de beurre de karité, et de pâte alimentaire. Les femmes du groupe KONOKOULOUDJELE sont à leur quatorzième prêt solidaire. Dans le but de satisfaire la demande énorme de leurs clientèles, elles font recours à SORO YIRIWASO. 
Ces montants seront utilisés pour acheter leurs marchandises déjà citées.
La cliente FATOUMATA la première personne à partir de la gauche dans le rang assis n’est pas instruite, elle est actuellement vendeuse de couscous séché. Elle compte acheter du sachet plastique, et 3 sacs de mil sur place au village. Elle le transforme en couscous sec et le produit final sera mis dans des emballages. La vente se fait uniquement chez elle en espèce et a une clientèle mixte. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 70 000 Fcfa qui sera utilisé pour assurer les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The group called Konokouloudjele is made up of married women with an average age of 48 and five children, on average. They all live in traditional families in the village of Bouya, commune of Banco,  Dioïla prefecture,  Koulikoro region (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

They know each other through bonds of family, neighborhood and friendship. They sell dried couscous, néré nuts, kola, karité butter, and pasta. The women of the group called Konokouloudjele are on their fourteenth solidarity loan. Wishing to satisfy the enormous demand of their customers, they have come to Soro Yiriwaso. Their loans will be used to buy the merchandise mentioned above. 

Fatoumata, the first person from the left in the seated row, did not receive an education. She is presently a seller of dried couscous. She intends to buy some plastic bags and three sacks of millet right there in the village. She will make the millet into dry couscous and the final product will be packaged. Sales are only made at her house, for cash, to a mixed clientele. She expects to make a monthly profit of 70,000 F CFA which will be used to cover the family's daily expenses.

loans.use: to buy millet to make into dried couscous

loans.name: Akur

texts.en:
Akur lives west of Bandung, about three hours from Jakarta. He manages a small shop selling mobile accessories and mobile phone airtime credit. Akur is married and lives with three persons in the family house.
	
Akur joined Ruma one month ago because he finds it interesting to sell mobile phone airtime credits. With assistance and support from Ruma’s staff, Akur sees improvements in his shop. For the last month, he has earned an average of $78 - $79 per day in mobile phone airtime credit sales. He hopes to get a Kiva loan as working capital to process more transactions.  

His goal for his business is to expand and have more new business in the future.

loans.use: to process more mobile phone airtime credit transactions on weekends.

loans.name: Orozkan

texts.ru: Орозкан 52 года, замужем, вместе с супругом воспитывают 5 детей. У Орозкан - среднее образование, в качестве основного дохода для своей семьи Орозкан занимается животноводством, стартовав 6 лет назад, с покупки скота на 10,000 сом KGS. Благодаря упорному труду Орозкан, в ее хозяйстве на сегодняшний день имеется: 1 дойная корова, 2 бычка, 20 овец. Ежемесячный доход составляет 20,000 сом (KGS). В целях дальнейшего развития своего хозяйства, Орозкан обратилась в Банк «Бай –Тушум» за кредитом - на покупку коров для увеличения поголовья скота. Доходы от кредита Орозкан планирует вложить в дальнейшее приумножение количества домашней скотины.
texts.en: Orozkan is 52 years old, married, and together with her husband, is raising five children. Orozkan has a secondary education. As the main source of income for her family, Orozkan practices livestock breeding. She started this business 6 years ago, with an initial purchase of cattle in the amount of 10,000 som (KGS). Thanks to Orozkan's hard work, she currently has 1 milk cow, 2 bull calves, and 20 sheep on her farm. Her monthly income is 20,000 som (KGS). For the purpose of further developing her business, Orozkan turned to Microfinance Bank "Bai Tushum." She is requesting a loan to buy cows to increase the size of her herd. Orozkan plans to invest the earnings from the loan in the further acquisition of livestock.

loans.use: to buy cows.

loans.name: Gulupa

texts.ru: Гулупе 34 года, замужем, вместе с супругом воспитывают 2 детей. У Гулупы - среднее образование, в качестве основного дохода для своей семьи Гулупа занимается животноводством, стартовав 10 лет назад, с покупки скота на 12,000 сом KGS. Благодаря упорному труду Гулупы, в ее хозяйстве на сегодняшний день имеется: 3 дойные коровы, 1 теленок, 10 овец и ягнята. Ежемесячный доход составляет 13,000 сом (KGS). В целях дальнейшего развития своего хозяйства, Гулупа обратилась в Банк «Бай –Тушум» за кредитом - на покупку овец для увеличения поголовья скота. Доходы от кредита Гулупа планирует вложить в дальнейшее приумножение количества домашней скотины, и планирует накопить средства на строительство нового помещения для скота.
texts.en: Gulupa is 34 years old, married, and together with her husband, is raising two children. Gulupa has a secondary education. As the main source of income for her family, Gulupa practices livestock breeding. She started this business 10 years ago, with an initial purchase of cattle in the amount of 12,000 som (KGS). Thanks to Gulupa's hard work, she currently has 3 milk cows, 1 calf, 10 sheep and lambs on her farm. Her monthly income is 13,000 som (KGS). For the purpose of further developing her business, Gulupa turned to Microfinance Bank "Bai Tushum." She is requesting a loan to buy sheep to increase the size of her herd. Gulupa plans to invest the earnings from the loan in the further acquisition of livestock. She also intends to save money to build a new barn for her livestock.

loans.use: to buy sheep.

loans.name: Sri

texts.en:
Sri lives west of Bandung, about three hours from Jakarta. She manages a small shop selling mobile accessories and mobile phone airtime credit.  Sri is married and lives with three persons in the family home.

Sri joined Ruma one month ago because she finds it interesting to sell mobile phone airtime credits. With assistance and support from Ruma’s staff, Sri sees improvements in her shop. For the last month, she has earned an average of $45 - $46 per day in mobile phone airtime credit sales. She hopes to get a Kiva loan as working capital to process more transactions.  

Her goal for her business is to expand to have more new business in the future.

loans.use: to process more mobile phone airtime credit transactions on weekends.

loans.name: Asesewa Group

texts.en:
These are the nine members of the Asesewa loan group. They are very humble, hardworking and responsible people with good manners and lots of enthusiasm for improving their lives. A few years back, they were all facing poverty, so they decided to join ID-Ghana to acquire loans to improve their businesses. They are into the sale of fish, sponges, firewood, underwear, toilet paper, cooking oil, slippers, kerosene and gari (which is made of cassava flour).

The featured borrower is Grace, who is 44 years old, married and has two children. In the picture, she is standing on the far right.  She earns a living by selling cooking oil, gari and diapers to help her husband financially. She has developed a very good relationship with her customers in the community and likes being able to meet their needs.

She has a plan to make her shop bigger and keep multiple items in it that her customers need. She wants to buy these items in bulk directly from wholesalers, and that is why she is requesting this loan.

loans.use: to buy and sell cooking oil, gari (cassava flour) and diapers to help her husband financially.

loans.name: Maria Ofelia

texts.es: María tiene 62 años de edad y habita en casa propia junto a su hija y dos nietos. María se dedica a la venta de  variedad de ropa para dama y para niños. De esta forma se gana la vida y lleva el sustento a su hogar. María y su familia habita en condiciones muy humildes y desea mejorar sus condiciones para lo cual solicita este crédito a FUSAI para invertir en la construcción de las paredes de la vivienda por material más resistente como: cemento, ladrillo, arena y hierro dado que actualmente están hechas a base de lámina y ya están deterioradas.
texts.en: Maria, 62, lives in her own house with her daughter and two grandchildren.  Maria has a business selling a variety of clothing for women and children.  This is how she earns a living and supports her household.  Maria and her family live in very humble conditions, and they want to improve their home.
